Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: A I04iend sends a text message complaining about having a long, boring day.
Expectation2: Recite and reflect on the Quran
Situation2: The community study circle convenes tonight to discuss verses the person has not yet read.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was about to open the Quran. It was Sarah, my closest friend, texting: “Ugh, today was endless. Can I vent?” I could almost hear the exhaustion in her words. I knew she needed me to listen, to be present, to offer the comfort I always tried to give. But tonight was also the community Quran study circle, and I hadn’t read the assigned verses yet. I felt the weight of my faith’s expectations—reciting and reflecting on the Quran, being prepared to contribute thoughtfully. The study circle was important to me, a chance to deepen my understanding and connect with others in my community. Yet, Sarah was reaching out, trusting me to be there for her. My heart tugged in two directions: the duty to my friend, and the responsibility to my faith. I stared at my phone, torn, feeling the pressure of both roles pressing in on me, unsure which to answer first.
